title: An Intro to Cloud Computing
description: an interactive workshop on how to launch an Amazon EC2 instance
contents:
fitvids('.shareagain', {players: 'iframe'});


Television
slides ~~ GitHub Square
source code



Overview
This workshop was originally developed for the Master of Environmental Data Science
(MEDS) program, administered by the Bren
School of Environmental Science & Management in partnership with
the National Center for Ecological
Analysis and Synthesis.
Abstract
“The Cloud” is a buzzword we often hear, but maybe don’t quite
understand. In this workshop, we’ll learn a bit about what cloud
computing means and what it can look like, how to launch a virtual
machine (i.e. an instance) using Amazon Web Services (AWS), and how we
can leverage more powerful computers (e.g. the cloud) to run
computationally-intensive processes in less time.

title: Intro to Shiny
description: a hands-on coding workshop on how to build a shiny app
contents:
fitvids('.shareagain', {players: 'iframe'});


Television
slides ~~ GitHub Square
source code



Overview
This workshop was originally developed for the Master of Environmental Data Science
(MEDS) program, administered by the Bren
School of Environmental Science & Management in partnership with
the National Center for Ecological
Analysis and Synthesis.
Abstract
Ever take a look at that beautiful data visualization you’ve worked
so hard on and think, “How awesome would it be if my audience could
interact with my data??” If so, building a shiny app might be just what
you’re looking for. {shiny} allows you to build interactive
web pages and dashboards from R. In this workshop, we’ll learn how to
transform your data into reactive outputs that you can share via a web
browser. Together, we’ll be build a shiny app that looks something like
this.

title: Data Science with R & Python
description: an R to Python (and vice versa) translation workshop in collaboration with Central Coast Python
contents:
Television
slides ~~ GitHub Square
GitHub Repo ~~ Video
recording ~~ Meetup
Meetup Event
Overview
This workshop was the result of a collaborative effort between the R-Ladies Santa
Barbara and Central Coast Python
Meetup groups. A special thanks to Sean Helvey for connecting with
us to make this happen!
Abstract
Python can be a powerful alternative/complementary language to R, and
while we here at R-Ladies are certainly partial to the latter, adding
another language to our data science toolkit is something we are always
excited for. In this R to Python (and vice versa) translation workshop,
we learn to wrangle and visualize the same dataset using both
languages.

title: RStudio Tips & Tricks
description: a talk on RStudio IDE tips & tricks and other keyboard shortcuts

Overview
This talk was originally developed for the Master of Environmental Data Science
(MEDS) program, administered by the Bren
School of Environmental Science & Management in partnership with
the National Center for Ecological
Analysis and Synthesis.
Abstract
As environmental data scientists, we spend a lot of time in RStudio.
Taking some time to learn how you can customize your RStudio IDE
(Integrated Development
Environment) and the keyboard shortcuts used to
navigate around that IDE can make you a more efficient (and happier)
hacker!

title: Teach Me How to Google
description: a talk on how to troubleshoot code and Google for helpful answers
contents:
fitvids('.shareagain', {players: 'iframe'});


Television
slides ~~ GitHub Square
source code ~~ plus
slide adaptations for invited talks ~~ Video
recording



Overview
This talk was originally developed for the Master of Environmental Data Science
(MEDS) program, administered by the Bren
School of Environmental Science & Management in partnership with
the National Center for Ecological
Analysis and Synthesis.
It’s since been given to students from UCSB’s Master
of Technology Management Program (Jan 2022), R-Ladies
St. Louis (Feb 2022), and The
Brown School StatLab at the University of Washington in St. Louis
(Mar 2022).
Abstract
Googling for code help is something that all data scientists (at all
career stages) do. But figuring out how to get the information you need
back can be incredibly challenging, particularly for new coders. In this
workshop, we’ll discuss strategies for refining your queries to increase
your chances of finding informative solutions.

title: Writing data science-related blog posts for your personal website
contents:
When you’ve written the same code 3 times, write a functionWhen
you’ve given the same in-person advice 3 times, write a blog post

— David Robinson (@drob)
November
9, 2017


Television
slides ~~ GitHub Square
source code ~~ Blog
blog post



Overview
This blog/workshop was originally developed for the Master of Environmental Data Science
(MEDS) program, administered by the Bren
School of Environmental Science & Management in partnership with
the National Center for Ecological
Analysis and Synthesis.
Abstract
Data science blogs have become increasingly popular – and for good
reason! They can be a fun way to learn a new skill and share it with
your online communities, and of course learn from others as well. Lucky
for us, the {distill} package makes it easier than ever to
curate your own blog. In this workshop, we’ll discuss different
approaches to blogging about data science topics and learn how to
customize our own blog posts using distill.

title: Customizing Your Personal Website with CSS
description: a brief intro to using CSS to customize {distill} websites
contents:
fitvids('.shareagain', {players: 'iframe'});


Television
slides ~~ GitHub Square
source code



Overview
This talk was originally developed for the Master of Environmental Data Science
(MEDS) program, administered by the Bren
School of Environmental Science & Management in partnership with
the National Center for Ecological
Analysis and Synthesis.
Abstract
Our MEDS students started off the inaugural year by learning how to
create their own personal websites using the {distill} R
package. This workshop offers an intro to CSS and how to use it to
further customize distill sites. We cover how to change the
default element styling (fonts, colors, sizes), how to create custom CSS
rules, and how to find inspiration from other distill websites (and
their source code) on the distillery.

title: It's ALL about semantics
description: a lightening talk on how semantic tools can make finding data easier and impactful synthesis science faster
contents:
Television
slides
Overview
This three-minute lightning talk was given at Santa Barbara Women in STEM’s
Lightning Talks (with a focus on software) event.
Abstract
Synthesis science, or the science of merging data from many different
sources to gain new insights, is critical for making predictions about
changes in the climate and environment and for helping us answer
questions about sustainably managing natural resources. However, in
order for synthesis science to be possible, data need to be documented
and stored in a way that makes them both discoverable and interpretable
by researchers. My team at NCEAS is taking a semantic approach to
curating environmental datasets – we develop controlled vocabularies, or
ontologies, that we use to annotate data records. This helps to both (a)
increase our understanding of the terms researchers have used to
describe their data by providing greater meaning and context, and (b)
increases the precision of our online data searches so that we more
confidently recover all available and relevant datasets.

title: Intro to the {tidyverse}
description: a code-along workshop to learn data wrangling and visualization techniques using {tidyverse} functions
contents:
Figure 1: An Bui and I getting ready to teach our very first
R workshop to R-Ladies SB, hosted at NCEAS




Markdown
knitted html ~~ GitHub Square
GitHub Repo ~~ Meetup
Meetup Event
Overview
My very first time (co)leading an R-based live-coding
workshop(!) and the experience that got me hooked on teaching
RStats/data science ❤️, given to R-Ladies Santa
Barbara.
Abstract
In this live-coding workshop, we teach useful functions for data
tidying, wrangling and visualization using tidyverse packages &
functions (e.g. dplyr, tidyr,
ggplot2, forcats, etc.). This session is
intended for R users at any level, whether it’s your first time
exploring the tidyverse or if you’re refreshing your wrangling
skills!
